  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XAQ experienced a UN1993 Fortis EC3071A release from a 200-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to complete a tote transfer. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-cup of product released to a 1' x 1â€™ area of the metal tote body due to a damage cap. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new metal tote. The damaged tote was wiped down for shipment back to the shipper. All impacted rags were containerized into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023070125
item.description:
Report E-2023070125

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-25T15:12:16+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-06
  • City: CLACKAMAS
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UPO experienced a UN3267 EDTA Acid Tetrasodium Salt 38% release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released to a 4' x 10' area of the trailer floor and a 4' x 10' area of the concrete lot below due to the tote being punctured by the trailer wall. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one and absorbents were deployed to clean all impacted areas. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: LANTAU HONG KONG
  • State:
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: PACKAGE WAS TRANSITING THROUGH HONG KONG FROM GUAM TO THE USA WHEN A DANGEROUS GOODS WAS DISCOVERED. OUTER BOX IS A PLASTIC PELICAN CASE CONTAINING MULTIPLE OFFICE SUPPLIES INCLUDING ONE X TEN OZ CAN OF INNOVERA DUSTER CLASSIFIED AS UN3159, REFRIGERANT GAS R134A. THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON A UPS FLIGHT FROM GUAM TO DISCOVERY IN HONG KONG. THE TRACKING THERMAL LABEL DESCRIPTION IS FEMA EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT. INVOICE DESCRIPTION IS FEMA IMAT EQUIPMENT. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER PELICAN CASE. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FORM GUAM USING UPS ACCOUNT 30250R, DHS FEMA REGION IX, 1111 BROADWAY, OAKLAND, CA 94607.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal ULV experienced a UN1993 Hydrite Blend 6 release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of product released to the trailer floor and a 50' x 20' area of the concrete lot below. The area was secured with boom and all released product was collected with absorbents. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon metal overpack. All impacted absorbents, boom, and cleanup debris were containerized into (2) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report X-2023070247

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-28T15:11:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-28
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: spilldevgrp@fedex.com
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 28th, a package was found on the belt during the sort that was leaking. The package had zero indications of containing and hazardous materials inside other than the name of the product Gravista Insecticide. Upon investigating the package an employee did come into contact with the chemical. The package was opened and two inner receptacles, each containing approximately 9.5 L were inside with one having leaked. It is unknown what caused the leak. After reviewing the SDS this is a UN3082 Environmentally Hazardous Substance, liquid, 9, PGIII shipment since the inner receptacles are more than 5L. The spill was cleaned up and the package was placed into a salvage drum and held at the station pending disposition

item.title: Report E-2023070244
item.description:
Report E-2023070244

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-28T15:11:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-23
  • City: BOSWELL
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 23, 2023, one (1) 50-pound bag of potassium hydroxide was damaged by a forklift and released approximately one (1) pound of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServce (ES) to remediate the impacted surface. Crews collected the damaged bag for disposal. ES personnel utilized hand tools to cut up the damaged pallet. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area. Once neutralized, ES personnel re-stacked the undamaged cargo for normal transport. All potassium hydroxide impacted material and damaged product was collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums and RLC personnel took possession of the waste to be added to the facility waste stream.

item.title: Report E-2023070240
item.description:
Report E-2023070240

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-28T15:11:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-22
  • City: MIDDLETOWN
  • State: DE
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 22, 2023, one (1) 50 gallon drum of sodium hydroxide was damaged by a load shift and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lewis Environmental Group (LEG) to remediate the impacted surfaces. LEG personnel deployed granular absorbents to the diesel fuel-impacted roadway and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents, broken down pallets and damaged drum were collected and containerized into one (1) roll over, one (1) 95-gallon poly drum over pack, and one (1) 55-gallon drum of solidified product for transport and disposal. LEG personnel re-palletized the freight and loaded a secondary trailer so the driver could move on.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XDM experienced a UN2289 718 I - Carboline CM 847 release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 240-gallons of product released to the trailer floor and multiple areas of the concrete lot below due to the tote being puncture by a loading bar. A skid steer was utilized to work sand and absorbents into the impacted areas. Citric acid was also deployed to neutralize the impacted areas. All impacted absorbents, the damaged tote, and two 55-gallon poly drums of impacted absorbents were staged into a roll off onsite pending disposal.

  • Description: On June 8, 2023, at 0000 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Midland, Texas regarding the release of approximately (1) gallon of CRW 9220 Corrosion Inhibitor (Flammable liquid, toxic, n.o.s., (Methanol, Isopropanol), UN1992, 3, 6.1, III) from (7) 55-gallon poly drums. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed that the release was contained to the tops of the drums only, contractors wiped down the totes and tightened the drum caps so the cargo could be forwarded on to the original consignee. All waste generated was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 21, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of NA1993 was damaged by a load shift and released approximately one-fourth (1/4) of a gallon to the trailer interior and pavement underneath the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Allied International Emergency Services (AIES) to remediate the impacted surfaces. Crews observed there was no product spilled and no spill to clean up. AIES personnel were unable to obtain a 330-gallon tote for a transfer. They will arrive onsite to complete the transfer the following day and this was approved by Ronald Stevenson. Crews secured the scene and demobilized. On June 22, 2023, AIES personnel arrived and assessed the site. Crews utilized a new 330-gallon tote to initiate, and complete a transfer from the damaged 330-gallon drum. One (1) 330-gallon damaged tote was staged onsite after transfer for terminal disposal.

DescribePack: Plastic closure seal had burst open halfway. 1/2 an inch of the seal had been opened. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed in a hazardous materials bin and was transported to designated hazmat cage.

  • Description: The truck and trailer hauling a water tank and agricultural sprayer was traveling south on a county gravel road 47th Ave. SW, 9.5 miles north of Hwy 21. Driver met an oncoming pickup truck, slowed down to 10 miles per hour and moved over to make room to pass the oncoming vehicle. The trailer wheels were pulled into the ditch as the soft shoulder of the gravel road gave way. As the driver continued forward the trailer pulled the truck drive wheels into the ditch and at this moment the truck and trailer tipped over. The IBC of the ag pesticide WideARmatch that was inside the secured carrier on the trailer deck flipped over and the product that was inside the IBC flowed out the 1-1/2 inch vent hole cap that is located on top of the IBC and it was in an open position to vent. That product spilled onto the ground and the release was about 10 minutes. Some product soaked into the ground and floor dry was placed on the remaining liquid pooled up under the shuttle.

  • Description: On June 16, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of disinfectant was punctured by a forklift and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer floor and asphalt below. R+L Carriers retianed Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted surface. he drum was collected and containerized into one (1) 95-gallon overpack drum for disposal. Crews deployed additional granular absorbents to the impacted area and worked them in with hand tools. Cleaners and absorbent pads were utilized to remove any residual product. The undamaged cargo was wiped down and repalletized for continued processing and shipping. All UN1903 impacted materials and spent absorbents were collected and containerized into three (3) 35-gallon drums for disposal. The drums were properly labeled, and possession of the material was taken by RLC to be disposed of through their bulk waste stream.

  • Description: While offloading a straight truck at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility in Menomonee Falls, WI, a 15 gallon steel drum fell over. As the drum fell, the contents of the drum shifted and created a spark which resulted in the lid shooting off. The Veolia employees offloading the truck witnessed a ball of light come from the drum. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the drum contained multiple lead acid batteries which were not protected from short circuiting as well as two luminous tube transformers. This incident resulted in a vapor release only, due to pressure build up with the drum. No amount hazard material was released as a result of the incident.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On June 15, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of hydrogen peroxide was punctured and released less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazMat Special Services (HMSS) to remediate the site. The 330-gallon tote of hydrogen peroxide had sustained damage to the top, but less than one (<1) gallon had released to the trailer. HMSS personnel utilized absorbent pads to wipe down the impacted trailer floor. HMSS personnel then transferred the product from the 330-gallon tote to another 330-gallon tote to be shipped off to its destination. The damaged tote was cut-up and placed into one (1) vented poly drum along with the used absorbent pads. This drum was staged on-site in the terminal's waste holding room for further evaluation.

  • Description: Package was offered to the spill office located at our hub facility located in Memphis TN when moisture and staining was seen indicating leakage from inside. Package was placed in a steel salvage drum and shipper was contacted for an amended shipper's declaration for return to shipper as FedEx policy does not for international shipment of salvage packaging.

  • Description: On June 15, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of sulfuric acid was punctured by a forklift and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ancon Services (AS) to remediate the impacted surface. AS identified the damaged pail and solidified the remaining contents in one (1) 30-gallon drum. AS deployed absorbents to the product on the concrete and utilized hand tools to collect the impacted solids in a separate 30-gallon drum. Both drums were labeled and staged onsite to be profiled by R+L personnel

  • City: Coldfoot
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: A specification cargo tank 1,000 gallons or greater containing any hazardous materials that (1) received structural damage to the lading retention system or damage that requires repair to a system int
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: WEAVER BROS., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A semi tractor was driving northbound on the Dalton Highway around Mile 126, approaching a curve that is colloquially referred to among Alaskan truck drivers as "Oh Shit Corner". The driver entered the corner at excessive speed, and immediately before the corner struck a large pothole in the road, which apparently caused two trailer tires to blow out, contributing to the loss of control in the corner. The tractor trailer combination rolled onto its side and departed the roadway, coming to rest beside and below the highway grade. The driver received only minor injuries and did not require transport for medical attention. At the time of the initial response, Alaska Commercial Vehicle Compliance and Alaska State Troopers believed there may have been a release due to the odor, however Suburban Propane (shipper) personnel arrived on the scene and reported there was no leak beyond normal vent operation. Personnel and equipment were mobilized to the scene, the product was transloaded into another tanker, and a wrecker removed the tractor and trailer and brought them back to Fairbanks. Professional traffic control allowed this to be completed without requiring a road closure.

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Allied International Emergency was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractorâ€™s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 10ft- by-10ft area of the terminal floor and estimated that twenty (20) gallons of material was released due to forklift damaging eighteen (18) 1-gallon plastic jugs. Allied International Emergency personnel separated the non-damaged plastic jugs and placed them on the side to be shipped onto the consignee. Allied International Emergency personnel neutralized the impacted area and deployed granular absorbents to collect the released material. Allied International Emergency personnel gathered all spent material and debris placed into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The impacted pallet was cut-up and placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The empty plastic jugs were placed into an additional 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LHO experienced a UN3082 CRODATERIC CAS 50-LQ-(MH) release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 6' x 6' area of the dock floor and a 20' x 24' area of the concrete lot below. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The material was transferred into a new tote. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into (3) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was removed from site pending disposal.

  • City: Elizabethtown
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CONNELL TRANSPORT CO. LTD
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While parked at rest stop, a leak was discovered coming from the weld seam on the tank truck. Glendale Fire Department responded to assess the site. First Call Environmental was dispatched to assess and perform cleanup. Upon arrival on site, leak was discovered coming from weld seam at back of truck, cause could not be determined. As product was coal tar pitch, heat was turned off inside tank, which caused product to cool and solidify over time. First Call Environmental monitored the site until no further release was detected and product had hardened within tank. First Call Environmental proceeded to scrape the product from the affected asphalt and surrounding seam on tank and recovered all product from the area. Disposal will be coordinated in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

item.title: Report E-2022090941
item.description:
Report E-2022090941

Identified by scraper @ 2023-07-26T00:36:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-02
  • City: RURAL RETREAT
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ENVIRONMENTAL OPTIONS INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Environmental Options Inc (EOI) truck was en route to Environmental Enterprises Inc (EEI) in Marion VA with a load of hazardous waste. The tractor became disabled on the shoulder of I-81 at MM 59.5 EOI contacted EEI to dispatch a tractor to the site, to pull the trailer to EEI Located in Marion VA. When EEI arrived they discovered a liquid leaking out of the nose of the trailer and thought a chlorine Vapor was observed when checking the load. EEI contacted Leann Herman with EOI. Ms. Herman then contacted the state police and First Call Environmental to respond to a hazmat incident. Ms Herman then reached out to Elizabeth Lohman with the Office of Pollution Response & Emergency Preparedness with the VA DEQ. Due to the hazmat on board and response time of 3 hours for First Call, Scott Sproles the Regional Hazmat officer with VDEM was dispatched to the scene and called in Wythe County Emergency Services to help. During this time the NRC, VEOC were also notified. DEQ contacted VDOT to dispatch the Safety Patrol Operator to evaluate the need for traffic control and a lane closure was put into place. The initial incident report to the NRC indicated chlorine tabs gassing off (Incident report 1346219). Once Hazmat crew was on scene and the load was transferred to another trailer, a leaking drum of nitric acid nickel solution was discovered. The drum had a small pin hole in the bottom of the drum causing the release . The leaking drum was overpacked and spilled material was neutralized and collected in a drum for proper disposal. Ms. Herman updated the NRC incident report to to show approximately 10 gallons of nitric acid nickel solution was released (Incident report 1346275). A follow up call was made on 09/03/2022 to provide updated information of the clean up. The material on the ground was also neutralized and will be collected into a drum and taken for proper disposal Incident report 1346306.
